### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Remote Working Software Usage On The Rise

Respondents also weighed in on their firms’ increased use of remote working software. Nearly half (46%) reported that their firms invested in remote working software as a direct result of the pandemic. This only makes sense since remote working tools were often the only way to get work done due to social distancing requirements.

According to the survey results, the most popular remote-working tools firms invested in due to the pandemic were video conferencing tools (32%), e-signature (22%), law practice management software (14%), time and billing software (13%), and communication software (16%).

Cloud Computing Is Now The Norm In The Legal Profession

Survey respondents were also asked about cloud computing software usage. The data showed that the pandemic had the effect of pushing the vast majority of lawyers into the cloud. Prior to the pandemic, 76% of law firms used cloud-based computing, and that percentage has now increased to 88%.

The firms that transitioned to the cloud since the onset of the pandemic have invested in a number of different types of cloud-based software. The survey results showed that law practice management software was the most popular at 23%, followed by document management software (13%), calendar management software (12%), and credit card online payment tools (12%).

The majority of respondents shared that their investment in cloud-based remote working software has been a favorable one with 73% indicating that the remote working tools their firms invested in had increased productivity. Another 80% reported that remote working tools were part of their firm’s long-term business continuity strategy.

Software Adoption Resulted In Law Firm Profit And Growth

The remote working technologies adopted by law firms during the pandemic not only bridged the gap, but, as discussed above, also increased the productivity and profitability of many firms, laying the groundwork for long-term business resiliency.

Notably, with that increased productivity came increased profit or revenue stability for some firms. According to the survey results, 60% of law firms’ revenue stayed the same or increased in 2020. Additionally, the survey respondents had a favorable outlook on the future, with more than half (59%) expecting their firms’ revenue would increase in 2021.

In November 2021, it’s clear that remote work is here to stay for the short term, at the very least. And, it will most likely become commonplace in the long term as well. This is because the pandemic’s effects pushed many law firms to acquire and implement technology that enables remote working. This technology investment ensures that resilience is built into their firms for the long term. So no matter what happens down the road, their firms will be fully operational despite unforeseen circumstances and are now better prepared for whatever the future may bring.

[Nicole Black](http://lawtechtalk.com/) is a Rochester, New York attorney and Director of Business and Community Relations at [MyCase](http://www.mycaseinc.com/), web-based law practice management software. She’s been [blogging](http://nylawblog.typepad.com/) since 2005, has written a [weekly column](http://nydailyrecord.com/blog/tag/legal-currents/) for the Daily Record since 2007, is the author of [Cloud Computing for Lawyers](https://apps.americanbar.org/abastore/index.cfm?fm=Product.AddToCart&pid=5110724), co-authors [Social Media for Lawyers: the Next Frontier](http://www.abanet.org/abastore/index.cfm?section=main&fm=Product.AddToCart&pid=5110710), and co-authors [Criminal Law in New York](http://legalsolutions.thomsonreuters.com/law-products/Treatises/Criminal-Law-in-New-York-4th-2013-2014-ed/p/100216297). She’s easily distracted by the potential of bright and shiny tech gadgets, along with good food and wine. You can follow her on Twitter at [@nikiblack](http://twitter.com/nikiblack) and she can be reached at [niki.black@mycase.com](mailto:niki.black@mycase.com).

At this rate, given how much the president likes him, let’s see if he’s still Deputy AG come May. According to LSAC, ASU is one of only four law schools in the country to have seen an increase in applications of 50 percent of more. [[ASU Now](https://asunow.asu.edu/20180206-asu-law-headed-toward-record-breaking-year-applications)] * "Jane Doe," the New Hampshire woman who won the $560 million Powerball lottery last month, has filed suit against the state’s Lottery Commission in an attempt to remain anonymous. # Movers, Shakers & Rainmakers: A New Legal Industry Podcast
## Are you a lawyer? Someone who hires lawyers? Do you care about the latest trends in Biglaw? Lateral Link has a new podcast for you.
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onNovember 12, 2021 at 12:12 PMNovember 12, 2021 at 8:41 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/movers-shakers-rainmakers-a-new-legal-industry-podcast/&text=Movers,%20Shakers%20&%20Rainmakers:%20A%20New%20Legal%20Industry%20Podcast)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/movers-shakers-rainmakers-a-new-legal-industry-podcast/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/movers-shakers-rainmakers-a-new-legal-industry-podcast/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Are you a lawyer? Someone who hires lawyers? Do you care about the latest trends in Biglaw? If so, you should be listening to [Movers, Shakers & Rainmakers](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website), a new podcast from Lateral Link. Hosted by [Zach Sandberg](https://laterallink.com/team/zach-sandberg/) and [David Lat](https://davidlat.substack.com/about?sort=about), the podcast provides a coast-to-coast view of what is happening in Biglaw. From major lateral partner moves to intriguing office openings to emerging legal industry trends, the podcast fills you in and lets you know what to expect.

So who are Zach and David, and why should you care what they think?

[Zach Sandberg](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zach-sandberg-5642012b/) is a Senior Director based in Lateral Link’s Los Angeles office. He focuses on placing attorneys at premier firms and corporations throughout California and the West Coast. With about a decade of experience in legal recruiting, Zach draws on his wide network of law firm sources to gain insight into the latest Biglaw trends.

[David Lat](https://davidlat.com/) likely needs no introduction. A renowned legal industry writer best known for founding Above The Law, David is an alum of Yale Law School, Wachtell, the Department of Justice, and Lateral Link. His latest project is [Original Jurisdiction](https://davidlat.substack.com/about?sort=about), a Substack newsletter that “aspires to be a source of incisive, fair-minded, and occasionally entertaining commentary about law and the legal profession.” David’s connections within the broader legal industry are second to none.

[](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website)
A Lateral Link Podcast Hosted by Zach Sandberg and David Lat.

The hosts typically begin with news about notable lateral moves and office openings, then spend the majority of the episode covering a broader industry trend. For example, in the [most recent episode](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website/episode-5-virtual-law-firm) (Episode 5), Zach and David discuss Davis Polk’s lateral hire of Cleary Gottlieb tax partner Corey Goodman and reflect on the retention challenge for Cleary’s lockstep model, versus Davis Polk’s newly more flexible compensation system. They also address the move of a highly-pedigreed five-partner litigation group from Munger Tolles to Wilson Sonsini and discuss Wilson Sonsoni’s opening of a Salt Lake City office. The majority of the episode is devoted to the growing trend of virtual law firms. Noting that a virtual firm, FisherBroyles, recently entered the AmLaw 200 for the first time, the hosts compare the economics of virtual firms to the traditional Biglaw model. They discuss the type of partner for whom the virtual firm model might be most advantageous, the extent to which virtual firms will appeal to associates, and the outlook for continued virtual firm growth.

In [Episode 4](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website/influx-of-international-legal-talent-to-the-us), Zach and David cover former Delaware Chancellor Andre Bouchard’s decision to join Paul, Weiss as a litigation partner in the Wilmington office, as well as Crowell & Moring’s office opening in Denver. They also talk about the notable uptick in 2021 of cross-border [lateral hires of international associates](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/international-lateral-moves/) by U.S. Biglaw offices. The hosts explain what is driving that trend, which countries are most favored for cross-border lateral hires, and whether the American Biglaw market is likely to remain open to international associates in the longer term.

[Movers, Shakers & Rainmakers](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website) has already addressed several timely topics, including [Biglaw Office Openings](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website/movers-shakers-rainmakers), the [Attorney Talent War](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website/episode-2-the-attorney-talent-war), and the [Future of Work](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website/episode-3-the-future-of-work). But the podcast remains a work in progress, by design. Zach and David are actively soliciting feedback from listeners about the topics they should cover. The goal is for the podcast to be as useful and informative as possible. The target audience is busy, and that’s why the hosts decided an audio format would be best. With a run-time around 30 minutes, the idea is to produce a product that busy lawyers can consume while on the go.

If you have suggestions for topics that [Movers, Shakers & Rainmakers](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website) should cover, please reach out to Zach Sandberg or David Lat, and let them know what you’d like to hear discussed!

For now, a new edition of [Movers, Shakers & Rainmakers](https://laterallink.libsyn.com/website) is being released every two weeks. If you’d like to be notified when a new episode is available, please [sign up here](https://app.laterallink.com/v1/register/start).

[Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/) is one of the top-rated international legal recruiting firms. With over 14 offices world-wide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. Managed by former practicing attorneys from top law schools, Lateral Link has a tradition of hiring lawyers to execute the lateral leaps of practicing attorneys. Click [here](https://www.laterallink.com/) to find out more about us.

# Yes, Going To Law School During The Great Recession Turned Out To Be A Terrible Idea
## New report confirms 2009-2017 grads screwed themselves/were themselves screwed.
By [Elie Mystal](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)  
onJanuary 16, 2018 at 2:46 PMJanuary 16, 2018 at 2:52 PM
461
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/yes-going-to-law-school-during-the-great-recession-turned-out-to-be-a-terrible-idea/&text=Yes,%20Going%20To%20Law%20School%20During%20The%20Great%20Recession%20Turned%20Out%20To%20Be%20A%20Terrible%20Idea)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/yes-going-to-law-school-during-the-great-recession-turned-out-to-be-a-terrible-idea/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/yes-going-to-law-school-during-the-great-recession-turned-out-to-be-a-terrible-idea/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We’re going to quibble about what “good job” means, but the upshot from an AccessLex Institute long-term study on law graduates is that going to law school was a bad call for most people over the past 10 years. Here it is [from the ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/less_than_half_of_recent_law_grads_had_good_jobs_waiting_for_them):

For respondents who graduated from law school during the Great Recession—which the report describes as being from 2009 and 2017—only 44 percent indicated that they had a “good job” waiting for them when they graduated. Of the post-recession graduates, 26 percent said that it took them more than one year to find a good job. Comparatively, only 10 percent pre-recession law graduates said that it took them more than a year to find a good job.

That is a pathetic rate, given the money required to get a law degree. And, speaking of money, the report has some data on that too:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[T]he report notes that for people who graduated from law school between 2010 and 2017, 60 percent borrowed more than $100,000 to pursue their law degree. Among those who graduated between 1990 and 1999, only 26 percent borrowed more than $100,000 for law school. And for those who graduated from law school between 1980 and 1989, 4 percent borrowed more than $100,000 for law school.

That’s where the market for legal education is so out of whack. The problem is not just that the “good” jobs are harder to come by, it’s that law school is wildly more expensive than it used to be. There are maybe 20 schools that are worth paying full price for. There are maybe another 20 schools that are worth it if you are getting reduced, in-state tuition. And that’s being extremely generous.

After that, borrowing over $100,000 to go to law school is just stupid. It’s been demonstrably stupid for going on 10 years now — unless you are going to one of the best schools, or getting a significant discount, or BOTH.

There’s not really anything surprising from the report, but apparently 53 percent of people who graduated during the Great Recession would recommend law school to somebody else. Which, essentially, is why Angie’s List can’t be trusted.

# Small Firm Lawyers Can Miss Out On Connections Formed At Larger Shops
## The social interactions that are available at larger firms are much harder to come by at a small law firm.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onDecember 15, 2023 at 1:16 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/small-firm-lawyers-can-miss-out-on-connections-formed-at-larger-shops/&text=Small%20Firm%20Lawyers%20Can%20Miss%20Out%20On%20Connections%20Formed%20At%20Larger%20Shops)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/small-firm-lawyers-can-miss-out-on-connections-formed-at-larger-shops/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/small-firm-lawyers-can-miss-out-on-connections-formed-at-larger-shops/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When I started [my own law firm](http://www.rothman.law) about five years ago, I knew there would be a number of changes in my work situation. For instance, my pay would vary greatly since I would no longer be receiving a salary from an employer. I also knew that I would have more control over my work situation since I would not have a boss telling me how to perform tasks for clients. However, I did not envision how I would miss out on the types of connections many lawyers make simply by virtue of working in the same workplace as other attorneys and staff.

When I worked at four different shops before starting my own law practice, I always enjoyed meeting new co-workers who had different experiences in the legal profession. The workday goes by a lot quicker when you have someone to talk to, and people at the firms at which I worked would generally stop by each other’s offices every so often to chat. Sure, some people mostly kept to themselves, which was fine. Moreover, if people work from home most of the time, they might miss out on interpersonal interactions with co-workers. However, the vast majority of people at the law firms at which I worked, from file clerks to the managing partners, interacted with other people while in the office, and this had a positive impact on the workday.

During the workday, I would routinely grab lunch with a group of people and bring it back to the office cafeteria so that we could eat together. Throughout the workweek, we would also dash off to coffee shops to pick up treats for ourselves and often for co-workers so that we could take a break from work and engage in something other than the practice of law. This has a positive impact on the workweek too since people are not exclusively in their offices working on client matters and have something to take their minds off of legal tasks.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
I also made a bunch of friendships with people I met through work. While working at various shops, I often met up socially with co-workers for drinks or meals in areas that were close to where we all lived. One time, I even organized a reunion of people who worked at a particular shop so that all of us could get together again even though many of us had stopped working there. Co-workers can form an important part of your social circle, and this is a beneficial aspect of working at a larger law firm.

Working with many other attorneys and staff can also yield professional benefits. The people with whom you work are likely to be important references if you decide to move on to new jobs, and may be positioned to give you work depending on where your career paths take you. For instance, I once worked at a large law firm in an office that had several dozen lawyers. Years later, those lawyers were all over the legal industry in the area in which I reside, including government, in-house counsel positions, and in other roles. I know that people have leveraged the fact that we all worked together to have access to so many people who can have a positive career impact.

When you are a solo practitioner or a small firm lawyer, you do not have the same connections with co-workers. For instance, the only other person who works at my law firm at the moment is my brother, and we had a pretty close connection before we started working together! The days can be a little more tedious when you are a small firm lawyer since you do not often have any co-workers to interact with. Moreover, it can be difficult to make career connections that can be beneficial, unless the small firm lawyer commits to bar association events and other networking opportunities to fill this gap.

I am not saying that interacting with co-workers is a substantial reason why people should work for larger firms, and indeed, individuals might prefer working at a smaller shop for many reasons. However, lawyers should keep in mind that smaller law firms have different work environments than larger firms and attorneys might not make the same connections as a small-firm lawyer than they would working at a larger employer.

# Major Biglaw Firm Shares The Wealth With Associates
## More good news for associates -- if you bill enough.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 5, 2021 at 10:04 AMApril 5, 2021 at 9:59 AM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/gdc-special-bonuses/&text=Major%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Shares%20The%20Wealth%20With%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/gdc-special-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/gdc-special-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
With widespread access to the COVID-19 vaccine approaching (or [even here for some states](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/what-you-absolutely-positively-need-to-know-about-booking-your-covid-vaccine-appointment-in-new-york/)), it really feels like the tide is turning and the awfulness of 2020+ will shortly be behind us. Another sign of improving times — at least in the legal industry — is the Biglaw COVID appreciation bonuses.

The spring special bonus trend is continuing. Associates at Gibson Dunn (a firm ranked 11th on the most recent Am Law 100 list) got word on Friday afternoon that they, like so many of their peers at other Biglaw firms, would be sharing in their firm’s good fortune during the global COVID-19 pandemic.

Gibson Dunn will be handing out bonuses according to the following schedule (April/October payment dates with the second payment larded up):

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  


But the catch is that, except for the brand new associates (class of 2020), the bonus payments are subject to a billable hours requirement. However, if an associate fails to meet that standard for the first payment, they will have the opportunity to make it up in time for the second. The firm also clarified these special bonuses are in addition to the usual year-end money. You can read the firm’s[ full memo on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/gdc-special-bonuses/2/)

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Morning Docket: 01.10.17
## * The confirmation hearings for Jeff Sessions to serve as U.S. attorney general get underway today; here's what to watch for. [[How Appealing](http://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/010917.html#070082)] * Biglaw faces big challenges today, and even top law firms need to up their game. [[DealBook / New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/09/business/dealbook/with-competition-fierce-even-elite-law-firms-resort-to-the-unusual.html)] * Jared Kushner, Donald Trump's son-in-law (and also holder of an NYU Law degree), will serve as senior adviser to President Trump; Kushner's lawyer, Jamie Gorelick of WilmerHale, dismissed nepotism and conflict-of-interest concerns. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/01/09/tumps-son-in-law-jared-kushner-expected-to-join-white-house-as-a-senior-adviser/?utm_term=.99dc6c9b085f)] * Speaking of conflicts, it's probably a wise idea for Supreme Court justices to unload their holdings of individual stocks -- as a recent snafu involving Chief Justice John Roberts suggests. [[New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/09/us/politics/the-hazards-justices-face-by-owning-individual-stocks.html?_r=0)] * Speaking of SCOTUS, the Court heard arguments yesterday in a case about a Colorado law making it more difficult for criminal defendants whose convictions get overturned to obtain refunds of fines and restitution they previously paid. [[How Appealing](http://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/010917.html#070079)] * Here is Chris Geidner's assessment of the where the Court is right now -- and how it might change after President Trump's first appointment, to be announced sometime after inauguration. [[BuzzFeed](https://www.buzzfeed.com/chrisgeidner/the-supreme-court-will-lean-conservative-again?utm_term=.ndVwxb0E7m#.ipqaWRDwmd)] * And here is a detailed dossier on one of Trump's [SCOTUS finalists](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/handicapping-donald-trumps-supreme-court-shortlist/?rf=1), Judge Neil Gorsuch of the Tenth Circuit. [[U.S. Law Week / Bloomberg BNA](https://www.bna.com/trump-scotus-shortlister-n73014449500/)] * What can we expect from the SEC if Sullivan & Cromwell partner [Jay Clayton](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/trump-nominates-sullivan-cromwell-partner-to-lead-sec/) is confirmed as chair? Thoughts from Peter J. Henning. [[DealBook / New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/09/business/dealbook/under-new-chairman-sec-enforcer-role-might-shrink.html)]
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)

# Morning Docket: 11.01.18
## * Supreme Court looks to further cripple class actions by killing off cases that chasten corporate misconduct but can't feasibly reimburse every individual victim. So, if you're planning to injure a bunch of people, make sure to do it in a small and difficult to track manner! [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/10/31/justices-frown-on-cy-pres-settlements-but-fate-is-uncertain/)] * Brexit comes to Biglaw as Kirkland moves its European hub to Paris. [[International](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/31/it-will-act-as-a-catalyst-partners-cite-brexit-factor-as-kirklands-paris-play-turns-heads-396-8655/)] * Biglaw associate suing USA Gymnastics for all the reasons USA Gymnastics is getting sued these days. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/31/big-law-associate-sues-usa-gymnastics-over-sex-abuse-scandal/)] * Tribes are suing North Dakota over its naked effort to disenfranchise Native Americans. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/10/31/tribes-sue-north-dakota-for-suppressing-right-to-vote-in-midterms/)] * Shocking absolutely no one, the EEOC finds that the #MeToo movement has not resulted in a surge in false allegations. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2018/10/31/men-are-worried-but-eeoc-panel-finds-little-evidence-to-support-metoo-backlash-fears/)] * This lawsuit against Spirit Airlines uses a lot of fast food analogies but misses the most apt: flying Spirit Airlines is like willfully going to the dirtiest Sbarro you can find and being shocked. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1097756/spirit-airlines-flyers-compare-burgers-to-baggage-fees)] * The legal battle over Selendy & Gay's billings following the departure from Quinn Emanuel pits contractual obligations against legal ethics. [[New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/31/forfeiture-contract-complicates-quinn-emanuel-spat-with-breakaway-partners/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onNovember 1, 2018 at 8:48 AM
1

# Top Biglaw Firm Announces New Spring Special Bonuses, And The Bonus War Is On!
## Let the Biglaw matches commence!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 24, 2021 at 2:13 PMMarch 24, 2021 at 10:22 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/milbank-match-spring-bonus/&text=Top%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Announces%20New%20Spring%20Special%20Bonuses,%20And%20The%20Bonus%20War%20Is%20On!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/milbank-match-spring-bonus/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/milbank-match-spring-bonus/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Woohoo! The Biglaw spring bonus wars are heating up!

Fresh off of news that [Willkie Farr](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/willkie-spring-bonuses-2021/) was handing out special spring bonuses in appreciation of associates’ hard work during a particularly trying period, and[ Davis Polk’s decision](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/davis-polk-spring-special-bonus-2021/) to outdo that generosity, Milbank has decided to throw their hat into the ring.

Today, the firm announced their own spring bonuses and matched the scale set by Davis Polk. The bonus distributions will be as follows:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
April	September	Total
Class of 2020	$4,500	$7,500	$12,000
Class of 2019	$6,000	$10,000	$16,000
Class of 2018	$12,000	$20,000	$32,000
Class of 2017	$16,500	$27,500	$44,000
Class of 2016	$19,500	$32,500	$52,000
Class of 2015	$22,200	$37,000	$59,200
Class of 2014	$24,000	$40,000	$64,000
Class of 2013	$24,000	$40,000	$64,000
Bonuses will be paid by April 30 / September 30, 2021. And yes, there will still be regular, end-of-the-year bonuses at Milbank: “These special bonuses will not impact any discretionary bonus paid in respect of 2021.” The firm announcement went on to note, associates can continue to expect big bucks come year-end bonus time too, saying, “We expect our year-end bonus will be no less than the 2020 year-end bonus levels for eligible associates.”

The full memo is available on the [next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/milbank-match-spring-bonus/2/).

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)

# Money Train Pulling Into Top 50 Biglaw Firm
## Big money coming to this Biglaw firm.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 18, 2023 at 1:34 PMDecember 18, 2023 at 11:46 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/foley-compensation-23/&text=Money%20Train%20Pulling%20Into%20Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/foley-compensation-23/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/foley-compensation-23/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The countdown to the end of the year has begun and that means ‘tis the damn season for compensation news! When Milbank raised salaries last month, then Cravath came over the top for midlevel and senior associates, it sparked a flood of firms matching those new compensation numbers.

The latest firm to get on the money train is Foley & Lardner. The firm made over a billion dollars in gross revenue last year — $1,080,332,000, to be precise — and they’re going to share that largesse with associates.

The new compensation grid at the firm is as follows — effective on February 1st:



The firm has maintained its[ tradition](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/foley-lardner-raise-2022/) of paying 2nd years slightly more than the industry average — the Class of 2022 will actually earn $5,000 more at Foley than at Milbank. However, the grid ends at the $420,000/class of 2017 line, where as several firms have placed an extra class or two on the grid.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter [@Kathryn1](%E2%80%9C//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22%E2%80%9D) or Mastodon [@Kathryn1@mastodon.social.](//mastodon.social/@Kathryn1%22)


##Enter your email address to sign up for ATL's Bonus & Salary Increase Alerts.

# You Don't Get To Be At The Top Of The Biglaw Heap Without Getting In On The Associate Raise Trend
## Skadden comes to the party.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 23, 2022 at 6:21 PMFebruary 23, 2022 at 7:00 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/skadden-raises-22/&text=You%20Don’t%20Get%20To%20Be%20At%20The%20Top%20Of%20The%20Biglaw%20Heap%20Without%20Getting%20In%20On%20The%20Associate%20Raise%20Trend)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/skadden-raises-22/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/skadden-raises-22/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The associate raises are coming in fast and furious.

Remember it was way back in January that Milbank made the first move in the 2022 associate salary wars. After *weeks* of (mostly) crickets, yesterday Davis Polk announced their own raises — a match of the Milbank scale for junior associates, but more money for midlevel and senior associates. And now the rest of the market is catching up.

Of course we *knew* that Skadden would pony up the money — the same money that its competitors are handing to associates. After all, the firm is ranked #5 on the Am Law 100 with an impressive $2,662,890,000 in gross revenue in 2020. And with the white-hot lateral market for associates, the pressure will be on for firms to match this standard.

This evening, the firm announced the following compensation scale:



These raises will be retroactive to January 1 — the same [effective date as the Milbank bump ](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/alert-milbank-announces-salary-scale-increases-to-kick-off-the-new-year/)— and will will hit bank accounts on March 15th. You can read the full memo [on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/skadden-raises-22/2/)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Digital Transformation Budgets
## Notes to my (legal) self.
By [Olga V. Mack](https://abovethelaw.com/author/olgamack/)

Olga V. Mack is a Fellow at CodeX, The Stanford Center for Legal Informatics, and a Generative AI Editor at law.MIT. Olga embraces legal innovation and had dedicated her career to improving and shaping the future of law. She is convinced that the legal profession will emerge even stronger, more resilient, and more inclusive than before by embracing technology. Olga is also an award-winning general counsel, operations professional, startup advisor, public speaker, adjunct professor, and entrepreneur. She authored [Get on Board: Earning Your Ticket to a Corporate Board Seat](https://www.amazon.com/Get-Board-Earning-Ticket-Corporate/dp/1949991407), [Fundamentals of Smart Contract Security](https://www.amazon.com/Fundamentals-Smart-Contract-Security-Richard-ebook/dp/B07S8YF27G), and  [Blockchain Value: Transforming Business Models, Society, and Communities](https://www.amazon.com/Blockchain-Value-Transforming-Business-Communities/dp/1952538246). She is working on three books: Visual IQ for Lawyers (ABA 2024), The Rise of Product Lawyers: An Analytical Framework to Systematically Advise Your Clients Throughout the Product Lifecycle (Globe Law and Business 2024), and Legal Operations in the Age of AI and Data (Globe Law and Business 2024). You can follow Olga on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/olgamack/) and Twitter @olgavmack.

# An Awkward Way To Go
## Lawyers can die at the craziest times.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 22, 2017 at 1:34 PM
4
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/an-awkward-way-to-go/&text=An%20Awkward%20Way%20To%20Go)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/an-awkward-way-to-go/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/an-awkward-way-to-go/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What lawyer, whose name still adorns a premier Biglaw firm, died while testifying before a Joint Committee of the U.S. Congress?

Hint: A former Treasury official, he was discussing Eisenhower’s Economic Report and died as he leaned forward to answer a question.

See the answer on the next page.

# High-Stakes Litigator Hangs It All Up To Spend Time With His Kids
## Retired at 50. #Goals
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 28, 2020 at 1:15 PMJanuary 29, 2020 at 9:37 AM
48
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/high-stakes-litigator-hangs-it-all-up-to-spend-time-with-his-kids/&text=High-Stakes%20Litigator%20Hangs%20It%20All%20Up%20To%20Spend%20Time%20With%20His%20Kids)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/high-stakes-litigator-hangs-it-all-up-to-spend-time-with-his-kids/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/high-stakes-litigator-hangs-it-all-up-to-spend-time-with-his-kids/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Earlier this month Brant Bishop left his practice at Wilkinson Walsh. The litigator, who also spent 18 years as a partner at Kirkland, is not leaving for another lateral opportunity, but just because he wants to spend more time with his family — he has a wife and five kids — saying, “I didn’t leave to go anywhere else except to go home.”

As Bishop [told Law.com](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/01/27/ex-kirkland-wilkinson-walsh-partner-calls-it-quits-to-escape-stress-and-just-go-home/), even when he was on vacation or otherwise away from the office, the demands of his practice — and the constant stream of emails — continued.

“Someone once said the law is a jealous mistress, and I think there’s some truth to that when you’re practicing at a very high level,” Bishop said.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
There wasn’t any particular bad experience that prompted Bishop’s decision. It was just the constant grind of elite legal work that made him hit pause on his career:

Bishop said there wasn’t a particular case or client or management responsibility—or a point in his personal life—that prompted his departure. Instead, he chalked up his decision to the inability to stop his work from encroaching on his personal time with his family, as well as the “nature of what we do.”

“It was very difficult to truly be away from the demands of running the firm, doing the management of the firm and doing cases,” Bishop said.

Bishop, who is 50 years old, says he might consider a reentry into the legal field someday:

“I may be too young to be permanently retired, so I don’t know if I’m retired in the sense that I’m not going to find something else to do at some point,” said the 50-year-old Bishop. “But for now the plan is to not really have much of a plan other than to spend time with family and keep my eyes open.”

# Biglaw Firm To Hand Out Year-End AND Special Bonuses -- If Associates Bill Enough
## Full market bonuses -- if you bill.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 7, 2020 at 3:15 PMDecember 7, 2020 at 2:39 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/kramer-levin-bonuses/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20To%20Hand%20Out%20Year-End%20AND%20Special%20Bonuses%20—%20If%20Associates%20Bill%20Enough)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/kramer-levin-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/kramer-levin-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

The Biglaw bonus season is revving into high gear as firms are setting out exactly how much they appreciate their associates. Of course, the market standard has pretty much been set — and it includes special bonuses that serve as an extra special tip of the hat for working during the wild ride that was 2020 — so it’s the small differences (like distribution dates and hours requirements) that make the most impact in categorizing a firm’s bonus structure.

On Friday, Kramer Levin announced year-end bonuses that match the prevailing market rate. The bonus scale is as follows ([you can read the full memo on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/kramer-levin-bonuses/2/)):

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Class of 2019: $15,000
Class of 2018: $25,000
Class of 2017: $50,000
Class of 2016: $65,000
Class of 2015: $80,000
Class of 2014: $90,000
Class of 2013+: $100,000

Plus the firm is finally on board with the special bonuses that became all the rage [among Biglaw firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/biglaw-fall-special-bonus-tracker-which-biglaw-firms-are-handing-out-cash-for-associates-hard-work-during-the-pandemic/?rf=1) starting in the fall, in appreciation of associates‘ hard work during the pandemic. Those special bonuses range from $7,500 to $40,000, depending on class year, and are in addition to the year-end bonus numbers. But there’s a catch.

While year-end bonus eligibility will be given out according to the standard firm criteria, that isn’t the case with special bonuses. The firm says “the special bonus is a one-time award that is designed to reward associates who made the most significant contributions to our clients’ and the firm’s economic success in a challenging year.” As such:

Eligibility to receive a special bonus will be based on an associate reaching a threshold of 1,800 bonus-eligible hours, of which at least 1,600 hours must be time spent on billable matters and/or partner-directed business development (as defined in the Annual Bonus Policy).

###Sponsored

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

It isn’t the most onerous hours requirement out there, but given the challenges of 2020, it’s still a significant chunk of hours to have to bill. And there’s no word on what happens if an associate just misses that threshold.

All bonuses at the firm will be paid on February 15, 2021.

As always, we depend on you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# High Minority Attrition Rates Continue To Plague Large Law Firms
## Columnist Renwei Chung highlights findings from the annual Vault/MCCA Law Firm Diversity Survey.
By [Renwei Chung](https://abovethelaw.com/author/renweichung/)  
onMarch 11, 2016 at 1:47 PMJanuary 5, 2020 at 1:28 PM
27
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/high-minority-attrition-rates-continue-to-plague-large-law-firms/&text=High%20Minority%20Attrition%20Rates%20Continue%20To%20Plague%20Large%20Law%20Firms)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/high-minority-attrition-rates-continue-to-plague-large-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/high-minority-attrition-rates-continue-to-plague-large-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
“In disbelief our belief is the reason for all this / The tallest building plummet, cracking, and crumbling.” – [Kendrick Lamar](http://genius.com/8766061)

This month, [Vault.com ](http://vault.com/)and [The Minority Corporate Counsel Association](http://www.mcca.com/) (MCCA) released their annual Vault/MCCA Law Firm Diversity Survey ([mcca.vault.com](http://mcca.vault.com)), the legal industry’s most comprehensive tool for measuring law firm diversity, collecting data on race, ethnicity, gender, GLBT identity, and disability status. The annual survey collects data based on the previous calendar year. Approximately 250 law firms participate in the survey each year, representing virtually all of the AmLaw 100 and a majority of the NLJ 250.

According to this year’s [report](http://www.mcca.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=page.viewpage&pageid=2624), despite progress in recruitment of diverse attorneys, problems at law firms persist concerning attrition and promotion. Here are some other highlights from their annual survey:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
- The diversification of law firms continues at a slow pace, as minority lawyers now represent 15.0% of attorneys at surveyed firms, compared to 13.8% in 2007.
- The hiring of African-American attorneys and law students has declined as their attrition has increased, resulting in law firms employing fewer black lawyers than they did eight years ago.
- Alongside the increased recruitment of minority attorneys, however, lawyers of color continue to leave their firms at a disproportionate rate.
- Moreover, advances among individual minority groups remain uneven, as the number of black lawyers declines and Asian American attorneys experience slower rates of promotion.
- Latina and Asian-American female partners are less than 1% of all law firm partners.
- Although Hispanic lawyers have made the most consistent advances, the number of Latino attorneys, relative to Latinos’ representation in the overall U.S. population, remains far lower than that of other minority groups.
After the [2009 economic crisis](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/12/what-could-disrupt-diversity-in-law-the-economy-stupid/), widespread layoffs caused women and minorities in law firms to decline for the [first time since the 1990s](http://www.nalp.org/2010lawfirmdiversity). According to NALP, “lawyer layoffs [disproportionately affected](http://www.nalp.org/2010lawfirmdiversity) junior and mid-level associate ranks, and because these groups of lawyers were among the most diverse in law firms, it is likely that these layoffs contributed in significant measure to the lower overall percentages that we [saw] in 2010.”

In 2010, the American Bar Association (ABA) highlighted a study that revealed [25% of law firms](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/about_25_of_law_firms_are_to_blame_for_high_minority_attrition_numbers_stud) are to blame for high minority attrition numbers. [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/2010/11/diversity-issues-to-consider-before-you-accept-your-offer/) also covered these findings. In this month’s ABA cover story, [“Minority Women are Disappearing from BigLaw and Here’s Why,”](http://www.abajournal.com/magazine/article/minority_women_are_disappearing_from_biglaw_and_heres_why/) Liane Jackson notes that 85% of minority female attorneys in the U.S. will quit large firms within seven years of starting their practice.

In [Joan Williams’s](http://www.uchastings.edu/academics/faculty/facultybios/williams/) study [“Double Jeopardy? – Gender Bias Against Women of Color in Science,”](http://www.uchastings.edu/news/articles/2015/01/double-jeopardy-report.pdf) her team interviewed 60 women of color in STEM. In the study, 100% of women of color experienced gender bias. In addition to gender bias, “Women of color also encounter racial and ethnic stereotypes, putting them in [‘a double jeopardy.’](http://fortune.com/2015/01/26/study-100-of-women-of-color-in-stem-experience-bias/)” Do [women of color](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/11/double-jeopardy-gender-bias-against-women-of-color-in-the-legal-profession/) face the same ‘double jeopardy’ problem in our profession?

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
It is no secret: high minority attrition rates remain a problem for law firms. However, a [number of law firms are tackling this problem](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/07/the-best-law-firms-for-diversity-2016/) and achieving progress with regard to diversity and inclusion. We still have a [long way](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/12/the-gilded-age-of-biglaw-biglaw-culture-breeds-big-bonuses-but-little-diversity/) [to go](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/12/ball-dont-lie-what-percentage-of-biglaw-partners-are-white/) when it comes to minority attrition rates in Biglaw, but these fine firms give us reason for hope.

[Renwei Chung](http://www.muckrack.com/renwei) is the Diversity Columnist at Above the Law. You can contact Renwei by email at [projectrenwei@gmail.com](mailto:projectrenwei@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column), follow him on Twitter ([@renweichung](https://twitter.com/RenweiChung)), or connect with him on [LinkedIn](http://www.linkedin.com/in/renweichung/).

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 04.16.18
## * Michael Cohen has until 2 p.m. this afternoon to produce the names of his clients with proof of their relationship, lest his attorneys' temporary restraining order over the alleged privilege of the "thousands, if not millions of documents" that were taken in the FBI raid upon his office get tossed. [[New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/2018/04/13/attorneys-for-trump-stormy-daniels-make-appearances-at-michael-cohen-tro-hearing/)] * In other news, President Trump wants to review all of the material that was seized by the FBI from his lawyer Michael Cohen before federal investigators are able to take a look at it -- after all, as the president says, attorney-client privilege "is dead." [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trump-wants-to-review-material-seized-from-personal-lawyer-before-federal-investigators/2018/04/15/c927d9f4-4115-11e8-bba2-0976a82b05a2_story.html?utm_term=.74b5e6585bd9)] * Many partners at Allen & Overy are "dead against" the firm's reportedly proposed merger with O'Melveny & Myers, which is probably just fine, considering the fact that O'Melveny "[has] no plans to merge [with A&O] and never [has]." [[Legal Week](https://www.law.com/2018/04/13/ao-faces-skepticism-over-omelveny-merger-as-doubts-emerge-among-partnership-396-2687/)] * Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein is supposed to make his debut at the Supreme Court later this month on April 23 to argue a case regarding sentencing guildelines on behalf of the United States government. We'll see how things go if he's already been fired by President Trump by the time oral arguments roll around. [[CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/13/politics/rod-rosenstein-supreme-court/index.html)] * According to Senate Republican Cory Gardner of Colorado, now that he's struck a deal with President Trump that will undercut Attorney General Jeff Sessions's recission of the Cole memo, he'll be happy to puff-puff-pass votes on all of the Department of Justice nominees he's been holding up. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-gardner-strike-deal-on-legalized-marijuana-ending-standoff-over-justice-nominees/2018/04/13/2ac3b35a-3f3a-11e8-912d-16c9e9b37800_story.html?utm_term=.e4b4c45ec118)] * "[T]op tier firms [must] take a more ‘people-centric’ approach, and break the tyranny of the billable unit as the overriding priority." This managing partner says that work/life balance and mental health for lawyers will never improve unless the legal profession addresses "onerous billable hour targets." [[Lawyers Weekly](https://www.lawyersweekly.com.au/sme-law/23063-law-firm-founder-calls-for-abolishment-of-onerous-billable-hour-tyranny)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 16, 2018 at 8:37 AMApril 16, 2018 at 8:13 AM
2

Michael D. Cohen

* Michael Cohen has until 2 p.m. this afternoon to produce the names of his clients with proof of their relationship, lest his attorneys’ temporary restraining order over the alleged privilege of the “thousands, if not millions of documents” that were taken in the FBI raid upon his office get tossed. [[New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/2018/04/13/attorneys-for-trump-stormy-daniels-make-appearances-at-michael-cohen-tro-hearing/)]

* In other news, President Trump wants to review all of the material that was seized by the FBI from his lawyer Michael Cohen before federal investigators are able to take a look at it — after all, as the president says, attorney-client privilege “is dead.” [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trump-wants-to-review-material-seized-from-personal-lawyer-before-federal-investigators/2018/04/15/c927d9f4-4115-11e8-bba2-0976a82b05a2_story.html?utm_term=.74b5e6585bd9)]

* Many partners at Allen & Overy are “dead against” the firm’s reportedly proposed merger with O’Melveny & Myers, which is probably just fine, considering the fact that O’Melveny “[has] no plans to merge [with A&O] and never [has].” [[Legal Week](https://www.law.com/2018/04/13/ao-faces-skepticism-over-omelveny-merger-as-doubts-emerge-among-partnership-396-2687/)]


* Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein is supposed to make his debut at the Supreme Court later this month on April 23 to argue a case regarding sentencing guildelines on behalf of the United States government. We’ll see how things go if he’s already been fired by President Trump by the time oral arguments roll around. [[CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/13/politics/rod-rosenstein-supreme-court/index.html)]

* According to Senate Republican Cory Gardner of Colorado, now that he’s struck a deal with President Trump that will undercut Attorney General Jeff Sessions’s recission of the Cole memo, he’ll be happy to puff-puff-pass votes on all of the Department of Justice nominees he’s been holding up. # Biglaw Bonus Announcement Is Just The Thing To Brighten Your Day
## Yay money!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 25, 2019 at 12:04 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/ao-bonus-2019/&text=Biglaw%20Bonus%20Announcement%20Is%20Just%20The%20Thing%20To%20Brighten%20Your%20Day)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/ao-bonus-2019/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/ao-bonus-2019/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Woohoo. The days before Thanksgiving — and (hopefully) some well-deserved time off — threatened to drag out like a game a Quidditch with a missing snitch, but thankfully a Biglaw firm decided to drop a bonus memo and snap us out of the doldrums.

And which firm has decided to delight its associates (well, at least the ones in New York, D.C. and Sao Paulo)? It’s Allen & Overy, who issued a match of the Milbank scale today. That grid is as follows:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Class of 2019 – $15,000 (pro-rated)
Class of 2018 – $15,000
Class of 2017 – $25,000
Class of 2016 – $50,000
Class of 2015 – $65,000
Class of 2014 – $80,000
Class of 2013 – $90,000
Class of 2012 – $100,000
Class of 2011 – $100,000

Bonuses will paid on January 15, 2020. ([Full memo on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/ao-bonus-2019/2/).)

Remember, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for all salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

# Another Top Biglaw Firm's Ransomware Attack Shows The Importance Of Cybersecurity
## Amazon and Google aren't the only ones interested in personal data. 
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onJuly 25, 2023 at 3:46 PMJuly 25, 2023 at 2:49 PM
17
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/another-top-biglaw-firms-ransomware-attack-shows-the-importance-of-cybersecurity/&text=Another%20Top%20Biglaw%20Firm’s%20Ransomware%20Attack%20Shows%20The%20Importance%20Of%20Cybersecurity)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/another-top-biglaw-firms-ransomware-attack-shows-the-importance-of-cybersecurity/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/another-top-biglaw-firms-ransomware-attack-shows-the-importance-of-cybersecurity/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When people think of legal movies, they usually think of [Legally Blonde](https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/legally_blonde) or [My Cousin Vinny](https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/my_cousin_vinny). But times are changing — they’d be better served if they thought about [Blackhat](https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/blackhat). Attorney-client privilege does wonders when an adverse party wants to compel you to disclose information, but it doesn’t do much in the face of key loggers. Cyber attacks are a real threat to firm security, and even large firms like Quinn Emanuel need to be wary of them. From [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/quinn-emanuel-reports-cyber-attack-involving-limited-client-data-2023-07-24/):

An electronic discovery vendor for U.S. law firm Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan suffered a cybersecurity attack that may have exposed client information, the firm disclosed to California authorities on Friday.

Quinn Emanuel confirmed to Reuters on Monday that “a third-party data center we use for document management for some of our clients became the victim of a ransomware attack” last year. It said the attack was “limited to a small portion of our clients and matters.”

As fortunate as it is that only a small portion of clients and matters were hit in the ransomware attack, none is always preferable. The list of Biglaw firms that have been hit by hackers looks like a who’s who of the industry: Jones Day, Gibson Dunn, Orrick, and others. Will your firm be the next to join the list? If you want to avoid that, your best bet would be to bolster your cybersecurity during the “just in case” phase rather than the “why didn’t we just factor it into overhead” one. Your clients and your PR team will thank you.

He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. You can reach him by email at [cwilliams@abovethelaw.com](mailto:cwilliams@abovethelaw.com) and by tweet at [@WritesForRent](https://twitter.com/WritesForRent).

# Embracing Uncertainty In The AI Landscape
## With AI, as with driving, it's best to slow down in uncertain conditions.
By [Olga V. Mack](https://abovethelaw.com/author/olgamack/)  
onOctober 16, 2023 at 2:45 PMOctober 16, 2023 at 1:21 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/embracing-uncertainty-in-the-ai-landscape/&text=Embracing%20Uncertainty%20In%20The%20AI%20Landscape)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/embracing-uncertainty-in-the-ai-landscape/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/embracing-uncertainty-in-the-ai-landscape/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Back in my teenage years, my dad was my favorite chauffeur. And chauffeur he did, all through high school, college, and even law school. Fast forward to my wedding day, when my dad told my soon-to-be husband about his new chauffeur duties. 

Instead, my new husband urged me to get my driver’s license. After one driving lesson together, it was clear I’d need a professional instructor — to keep us safe on the road and to keep our newlywed bliss intact.

During a lesson, speeding around a curve under the blinding sun, my instructor said, “You have skills and a knack for risk. But remember, it’s best to slow down in uncertain conditions.”

That is also fantastic advice for approaching AI. Recent advancements in AI are thrilling! But in today’s rapidly changing landscape, caution is essential, especially as we are still figuring out legal policies, procedures, and best practices. 

Many questions still need to be answered. We’re not even sure we know all the right questions yet. But to make the most informed decisions now, it helps to first become comfortable with our uncertainty. Let’s look at how to embrace and navigate this inevitable aspect of the AI landscape. 

Education: The First Line Of Defense Against Uncertainty

As AI technology advances, new challenges and risks emerge. Issues regarding privacy, security, bias, and ethical implications arise. You must understand the cause-and-effect relationships of these risks to develop effective mitigation strategies. 

Stay updated on AI technology developments to navigate uncertainty. Consider these [Ongoing AI Education Strategies and Resources for Lawyers](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/ongoing-ai-education-strategies-and-resources-for-lawyers/). Attend conferences, read research papers, and follow industry experts and thought leaders on social media. Learn how the latest AI developments can potentially impact various industries and society as a whole. 

As you incorporate new information into your practice, you learn to better adapt to the evolving AI landscape and identify the challenges ahead. Over time, you prepare to proactively address those challenges head-on.

Focus On Policy Questions First

As AI evolves, policymakers face the challenge of creating regulations that balance the unrelenting demand for fast innovation with the necessary deference to ethical concerns such as fairness, transparency, accountability, and inclusivity.

One of the best ways to understand AI is to initially focus on the current policy questions and concerns surrounding its implementation. When you actively follow and participate in discussions around policy-making, you can personally contribute to shaping the future of responsible AI. Groups actively tracking or engaging in policy processes now include: 

- [MIT Task Force on the Responsible Use of Generative AI for Law](https://law.mit.edu/ai)
- [Center for AI and Digital Policy](https://www.caidp.org)
- [AI Now Institute](https://ainowinstitute.org/our-work)
Start Small In Low-Risk Areas

Experiment with AI technologies in controlled environments and pilot projects to gain practical experience. Start small in a low-risk area to ramp up the excitement while minimizing potential negative impacts. Through this approach, you learn from your mistakes and can refine strategies before implementing them more broadly. 

Balancing Your Approach To AI

Skepticism complements open-mindedness when facing uncertainty in the AI landscape. While many race to embrace the potential benefits of AI, business leaders depend on lawyers to critically evaluate its limitations and potential risks. In maintaining a balanced approach, you can help companies make more informed decisions and avoid unquestioningly adopting inappropriate AI tools. 

While we’re all in the driver’s seat and at the starting position, let’s embrace the unknowns of AI together and explore the exciting possibilities it holds. By staying curious, informed, and adaptable, we can confidently navigate the intersection of AI and law and make the most of what AI offers.

Olga V. Mack is the VP at [LexisNexis](https://www.lexisnexis.com/) and CEO of [Parley Pro](https://parleypro.com/), a next-generation contract management company that has pioneered online negotiation technology. Olga embraces legal innovation and had dedicated her career to improving and shaping the future of law. She is convinced that the legal profession will emerge even stronger, more resilient, and more inclusive than before by embracing technology. Olga is also an award-winning general counsel, operations professional, startup advisor, public speaker, adjunct professor, and entrepreneur. She founded the [Women Serve on Boards](https://www.womenserveonboards.com/) movement that advocates for women to participate on corporate boards of Fortune 500 companies. She authored [Get on Board: Earning Your Ticket to a Corporate Board Seat](https://www.amazon.com/Get-Board-Earning-Ticket-Corporate/dp/1949991407), [Fundamentals of Smart Contract Security](https://www.amazon.com/Fundamentals-Smart-Contract-Security-Richard-ebook/dp/B07S8YF27G), and  [Blockchain Value: Transforming Business Models, Society, and Communities](https://www.amazon.com/Blockchain-Value-Transforming-Business-Communities/dp/1952538246). She is working on Visual IQ for Lawyers, her next book (ABA 2023). You can follow Olga on Twitter @olgavmack.

# Am Law Top 20 Firm Announces... Raises? It's Hard To Tell From This Announcement
## Big firm issues raises for one class in one office. So far everything else is up in the air.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 21, 2016 at 3:34 PMJune 21, 2016 at 5:02 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/am-law-top-20-firm-announces-raises-its-hard-to-tell-from-this-announcement/&text=Am%20Law%20Top%2020%20Firm%20Announces…%20Raises?%20It’s%20Hard%20To%20Tell%20From%20This%20Announcement)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/am-law-top-20-firm-announces-raises-its-hard-to-tell-from-this-announcement/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/am-law-top-20-firm-announces-raises-its-hard-to-tell-from-this-announcement/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We’ve had firms announce raises, we’ve had firms [preach caution](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/one-firm-decides-to-pump-the-brakes-on-this-whole-raise-thing/), we’ve had firms preach caution and then [realize which way the wind blows](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-firm-changes-course-on-associate-compensation/), and we’ve had firms try [to clumsily pull off radio silence](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/these-partners-desperately-dont-want-us-to-know-they-arent-raising-salaries/). Now we have a complete mixed bag — akin to what we heard [from K&L Gates](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/a-biglaw-behemoths-weak-sauce-raise/) yesterday.

Honestly, we had given up hope on Greenberg Traurig. First, we got reports out of some of its smaller market offices that the partners considered raises and opted against them. Then even tipsters in New York expressed gloom and doom at the prospect of raises:

We received an email this morning that there will be an associates meeting with managing partners this afternoon to discuss “important issues.”

Wouldn’t be surprised if they say no and are trying to deal with optics.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
But this afternoon we’ve learned that Greenberg Traurig matched the $180K salary for its New York first years. The raises are effective July 1. The firm declined to issue a memo and opted to inform associates directly in an office meeting.

Beyond that though, associates are at the whim of the firm’s black box policy of determining pay based on productivity, group needs, etc. Tipsters seem pretty confident that this is the firm’s way of claiming matching status without really matching. As we hear more from individual associates we’ll get a clearer picture, but early reactions suggest they expect to be shortchanged compared to their peers going forward.

In an [earlier post on leverage](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/dont-just-shame-firms-based-on-profits-per-partner-consider-leverage/), I raised Greenberg Traurig as a firm whose leverage may be an obstacle in the raise process. One tipster took issue with this, noting that Greenberg maintains tiers of partnership that all have varying levels of equity, while the reported figures reflect only those partners on the top rung. In other words, the figures artificially inflate the associate to partner ratio. And that’s fair… but it still means the people with the most equity to lose heavily outnumber the associates. So while 4.4:1 may be high, this is still a leveraged firm.

And this just might be how a leveraged firm splits the baby, with raises only where they were absolutely necessary — first-year associates in the New York office — giving a little to the NYC mid-levels and seniors, and then nothing everywhere else.

UPDATE (6/21/16 5:01 p.m.): We’ve now heard from Chicago:

GT Chicago to $180,000. No announcement as to when. No announcement as to Summers. Individual raises communicated individually.

Sounds basically in line with NYC.

# Gigantic Biglaw Salaries Are Making Associates Reconsider Taking Pay Cuts To Go In-House
## Those in-house pastures aren't quite as green anymore.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 1, 2022 at 3:03 PMFebruary 1, 2022 at 3:12 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/gigantic-biglaw-salaries-are-making-associates-reconsider-taking-pay-cuts-to-go-in-house/&text=Gigantic%20Biglaw%20Salaries%20Are%20Making%20Associates%20Reconsider%20Taking%20Pay%20Cuts%20To%20Go%20In-House)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/gigantic-biglaw-salaries-are-making-associates-reconsider-taking-pay-cuts-to-go-in-house/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/gigantic-biglaw-salaries-are-making-associates-reconsider-taking-pay-cuts-to-go-in-house/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The reality from where I sit as a recruiter is that when we approach in-house candidates with great opportunities, they often stop listening once they find out it could be a 30-50% pay cut.

— Legal search consultant Stacy Humphries of the Pye Legal Group in Houston, Texas, explaining how the latest [Biglaw salary wars](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/biglaw-raise-tracker-2022/) have [impacted in-house recruiting](https://www.law.com/2022/01/31/big-law-salary-war-throws-cold-water-on-in-house-recruiting/). “It’s not good for big firm lawyers who won’t have as many in-house options available to them or will have to work hard to convince companies that they sincerely want to go in-house and will stay,” Humphries wrote in a [popular LinkedIn post](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6889979145292537856/). “These salary wars are not good. Change my mind.”

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).
